📚 ClaseB1
Notas Generales
Objetivo

Lograr que los estudiantes pasen con éxito todas las habilidades y demuestren que tienen los conocimientos necesarios que se requieren para ser certificados como un hablante de inglés en nivel A1

¿Hasta dónde se evalua en esta prueba?

Esta semana se estudia desde el módulo AQUÍ INICIAS EL NIVEL A2 hasta el módulo Semana 18: A2 TESTS PARA APROBAR EL NIVEL A2

Notas profesor

Este es el formato que el docente debe llenar https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1M6ymm7p4ZyLHwivDCiutwZ9XufRZbJIzYYVEzYUS3Yw/edit?gid=0#gid=0

Saludos

Los saludos deben ser reales. Un estudiante dice un saludo a otro compañero y este debe darle una respuesta.

Saludos Básicos

Palabra

Traducción

Frase Ejemplo

Traducción Frase Ejemplo

Hi

Hola

Hi! How are you?

¡Hola! ¿Cómo estás?

Hello

Hola

Hello, nice to meet you!

¡Hola, un placer conocerte!

Good morning

Buenos días

Good morning, everyone!

¡Buenos días a todos!

Good afternoon

Buenas tardes

Good afternoon, sir.

Buenas tardes, señor.

Good evening

Buenas noches

Good evening, how was your day?

Buenas noches, ¿cómo estuvo tu día?

Hey

Hola (informal)

Hey, what’s up?

¡Hola! ¿Qué pasa?

What’s up?

¿Qué tal?

What’s up, buddy?

¿Qué tal, amigo?

How are you?

¿Cómo estás?

How are you today?

¿Cómo estás hoy?

How’s it going?

¿Cómo va todo?

How’s it going at work?

¿Cómo va todo en el trabajo?

How do you do?

¿Cómo está usted?

How do you do, Mr. Smith?

¿Cómo está, Sr. Smith?
Saludos Intermedios

How have you been?

¿Cómo has estado?

How have you been lately?

¿Cómo has estado últimamente?

Long time no see

¡Cuánto tiempo!

Long time no see, my friend!

¡Cuánto tiempo, amigo!

Nice to see you

Gusto en verte

Nice to see you again!

¡Gusto en verte de nuevo!

It’s been a while

Ha pasado tiempo

It’s been a while since we met.

Ha pasado tiempo desde que nos vimos.

How’s everything?

¿Cómo va todo?

How’s everything at home?

¿Cómo va todo en casa?

How’s your day?

¿Cómo ha sido tu día?

How’s your day so far?

¿Cómo ha sido tu día hasta ahora?

What’s new?

¿Qué hay de nuevo?

What’s new with you?

¿Qué hay de nuevo contigo?

How’s life?

¿Cómo va la vida?

How’s life treating you?

¿Cómo te trata la vida?

How’s work?

¿Cómo va el trabajo?

How’s work these days?

¿Cómo va el trabajo estos días?

How’s your family?

¿Cómo está tu familia?

How’s your family doing?

¿Cómo está tu familia?
Saludos Avanzados

Greetings

Saludos

Greetings, colleagues!

¡Saludos, colegas!

Pleasure to meet you

Un placer conocerte

Pleasure to meet you in person!

¡Un placer conocerte en persona!

What have you been up to?

¿En qué has estado?

What have you been up to lately?

¿En qué has estado últimamente?

How’s your week going?

¿Cómo va tu semana?

How’s your week going so far?

¿Cómo va tu semana hasta ahora?

It’s a pleasure to see you again

Es un placer verte de nuevo

It’s a pleasure to see you again after so long.

Es un placer verte de nuevo después de tanto tiempo.
B1 Evaluación Vocabulario
Capacidad: ¿Qué va a hacer el profesor?
  1. Muestra una lectura al estudiante y esté debe traducir lo que dice ese texto. Obs: Si el estudiante no puede interpretar lo que está leyendo, debe decir el significado de las palabras. Las palabras en negrita dentro de los textos indican palabras claves que tuvieron un refuerzo especial en la plataforma
  2. También debe hacer la prueba del ANKI: Cada estudiante abre su ANKI y va diciendo el significado de cada una de las tarjetas. Debe hacer un mínimo de 10 tarjetas en 1 minutos
Evaluación: ¿Qué debe poder hacer el estudiante?

Ser capaz de reconocer el significado de la palabra

Lecturas para evaluar el vocabulario
Evaluación 1 Vocabulario Nivel B1

Reading Text (Students’ Version):

When I was ten, I wanted to make something special. I thought, “What can I do? I like animals.” That was the time I decided to build a small shelter. I had no money, just an idea and a dream. I asked my brother to help him clean the garden. He didn’t know why, but he said yes.

We had to take boxes and wood from the garage. Many people don’t go into old places, but we were excited. That year, the winter was cold, and I wanted to help. I said, “Keep your gloves on! It’s not safe.” He smiled. We found some tools and started working. I thought we could build something warm for stray cats and keep them safe.

On Sunday, we worked together. I felt happy to see our project grow. We painted it and added a roof. The other kids helped too. I was proud, more than ever before. Then my mom came outside. “Wow! You did this?” she asked. I said, “Yes, and now we want to help more animals.”

She took a look and said it was not only cute, but useful too. She asked if more kids would come and help again. I hoped so. The shelter had its own style and color. I put a note over the door: “Safe place for all.”

I think helping others is the best feeling. My mom also gave us hot chocolate and snacks. We sat back and smiled. After that day, we wanted to use our free time to build two more shelters. We learned how to do things with our hands and heart.

That was our best family project. We had to work hard, but it felt right. The first shelter helped a kitten that was sick. We cared for it and it got well again. Helping animals is a way to grow kindness. Even now, I remember that feeling.

It taught me to create new things, and to always want to help, because small actions can change lives. I don’t need any reward. I only need to see the animals happy.

These shelters became more than boxes. They give safety, and hope. That day, we started something real. The most special part was doing it together. It helped us understand that kindness is powerful.

Reading Text (Teacher’s Version):

When (1) I was ten, I wanted to make (2) something special. I thought, “What can (3) I do? I like (4) animals.” That was the time (5) I decided to build a small shelter. I had no (6) money, just (7) an idea and a dream. I asked my brother to help him (8) clean the garden. He didn’t know (9) why, but he said yes.

We had to take (10) boxes and wood from the garage. Many people (11) don’t go into (12) old places, but we were excited. That year (13), the winter was cold, and I wanted to help. I said, “Keep your (14) gloves on! It’s not safe.” He smiled. We found some (15) tools and started working. I thought we could (16) build something warm for stray cats and keep them (17) safe.

On Sunday, we worked together. I felt happy to see (18) our project grow. We painted it and added a roof. The other (19) kids helped too. I was proud, more than (20) ever before. Then (21) my mom came outside. “Wow! You did this?” she asked. I said, “Yes, and now (22) we want to help more animals.”

She took a look (23) and said it was not only (24) cute, but useful too. She asked if more kids would come (25) and help again. I hoped so. The shelter had its (26) own style and color. I put a note over (27) the door: “Safe place for all.”

I think (28) helping others is the best feeling. My mom also (29) gave us hot chocolate and snacks. We sat back (30) and smiled. After (31) that day, we wanted to use (32) our free time to build two (33) more shelters. We learned how (34) to do things with our hands and heart.

That was our (35) best family project. We had to work (36) hard, but it felt right. The first (37) shelter helped a kitten that was sick. We cared for it and it got well (38) again. Helping animals is a way (39) to grow kindness. Even (40) now, I remember that feeling.

It taught me to create new (41) things, and to always want (42) to help, because (43) small actions can change lives. I don’t need any (44) reward. I only need to see the animals happy.

These (45) shelters became more than boxes. They give (46) safety, and hope. That day (47), we started something real. The most (48) special part was doing it together. It helped us (49) understand that kindness is powerful.

Evaluación 2 Vocabulario Nivel B1

Reading Text (Students’ Version): 2

When I was ten, I wanted to make something special. I thought, “What can I do? I like animals.” That was the time I decided to build a small shelter. I had no money, just an idea and a dream. I asked my brother to help him clean the garden. He didn’t know why, but he said yes.

We had to take boxes and wood from the garage. Many people don’t go into old places, but we were excited. That year, the winter was cold, and I wanted to help. I said, “Keep your gloves on! It’s not safe.” He smiled. We found some tools and started working. I thought we could build something warm for stray cats and keep them safe.

On Sunday, we worked together. I felt happy to see our project grow. We painted it and added a roof. The other kids helped too. I was proud, more than ever before. Then my mom came outside. “Wow! You did this?” she asked. I said, “Yes, and now we want to help more animals.”

She took a look and said it was not only cute, but useful too. She asked if more kids would come and help again. I hoped so. The shelter had its own style and color. I put a note over the door: “Safe place for all.”

I think helping others is the best feeling. My mom also gave us hot chocolate and snacks. We sat back and smiled. After that day, we wanted to use our free time to build two more shelters. We learned how to do things with our hands and heart.

That was our best family project. We had to work hard, but it felt right. The first shelter helped a kitten that was sick. We cared for it and it got well again. Helping animals is a way to grow kindness. Even now, I remember that feeling.

It taught me to create new things, and to always want to help, because small actions can change lives. I don’t need any reward. I only need to see the animals happy.

These shelters became more than boxes. They give safety, and hope. That day, we started something real. The most special part was doing it together. It helped us understand that kindness is powerful.

Reading Text (Teacher’s Version): 2

When (1) I was ten, I wanted to make (2) something special. I thought, “What can (3) I do? I like (4) animals.” That was the time (5) I decided to build a small shelter. I had no (6) money, just (7) an idea and a dream. I asked my brother to help him (8) clean the garden. He didn’t know (9) why, but he said yes.

We had to take (10) boxes and wood from the garage. Many people (11) don’t go into (12) old places, but we were excited. That year (13), the winter was cold, and I wanted to help. I said, “Keep your (14) gloves on! It’s not safe.” He smiled. We found some (15) tools and started working. I thought we could (16) build something warm for stray cats and keep them (17) safe.

On Sunday, we worked together. I felt happy to see (18) our project grow. We painted it and added a roof. The other (19) kids helped too. I was proud, more than (20) ever before. Then (21) my mom came outside. “Wow! You did this?” she asked. I said, “Yes, and now (22) we want to help more animals.”

She took a look (23) and said it was not only (24) cute, but useful too. She asked if more kids would come (25) and help again. I hoped so. The shelter had its (26) own style and color. I put a note over (27) the door: “Safe place for all.”

I think (28) helping others is the best feeling. My mom also (29) gave us hot chocolate and snacks. We sat back (30) and smiled. After (31) that day, we wanted to use (32) our free time to build two (33) more shelters. We learned how (34) to do things with our hands and heart.

That was our (35) best family project. We had to work (36) hard, but it felt right. The first (37) shelter helped a kitten that was sick. We cared for it and it got well (38) again. Helping animals is a way (39) to grow kindness. Even (40) now, I remember that feeling.

It taught me to create new (41) things, and to always want (42) to help, because (43) small actions can change lives. I don’t need any (44) reward. I only need to see the animals happy.

These (45) shelters became more than boxes. They give (46) safety, and hope. That day (47), we started something real. The most (48) special part was doing it together. It helped us (49) understand that kindness is powerful.

Evaluación 3 Vocabulario Nivel B1

Reading Text (Students’ Version): 3

There was a very young girl who loved her family a lot. She was such a happy child even when things were down. She may not have had much money, but she should never give up.

One day, she heard a call from the world outside her village. She went to school, but she was still curious about what was through the big forest near her home.

She wanted to live a full life, so she decided to try something new. The last day of school, she asked her teacher if she could explore. She knew she need to be careful, but she felt ready.

There were three paths in the forest, and she didn’t know when she would return. The state of her mind was calm, even though she had never been so far from home.

She wanted to become brave. The forest was a place between her village and the unknown. The trees were high, and it was really beautiful.

She found something special — a most amazing flower. She picked another one for her mother. She loved her family and wanted to have her own garden like this someday.

After walking out of the forest, she did not want to leave that feeling behind. She carefully put the flowers in her bag. The old forest had taught her a lesson.

While she was walking back, she thought about what the flowers mean. She promised to keep exploring as a student of life. She wondered why some people never try new things.

She decided to let her heart lead her. It was a great feeling to find the same courage others looked for in big adventures. The forest was a big part of her story now.

Reading Text (Teacher’s Version): 3

There was (1) a very young girl who loved (2) her family a lot. She was such (3) a happy child (4) even when things were down (5). She may (6) not have had much money, but she should (7) never give up.

One day, she heard a call (8) from the world (9) outside her village. She went to school (10), but she was still (11) curious about what was through (12) the big forest near her home.

She wanted to live a full life (13), so she decided to try (14) something new. The last (15) day of school, she asked (16) her teacher if she could explore. She knew she need (17) to be careful, but she felt (18) ready.

There were three (19) paths in the forest, and she didn’t know when (20) she would return. The state (21) of her mind was calm, even though she had never (22) been so far from home.

She wanted to become (23) brave. The forest was a place between (24) her village and the unknown. The trees were high (25), and it was really (26) beautiful.

She found something (27) special — a most (28) amazing flower. She picked another (29) one for her mother. She loved her family (30) and wanted to have her own (31) garden like this someday.

After walking out (32) of the forest, she did not want to leave (33) that feeling behind. She carefully put (34) the flowers in her bag. The old (35) forest had taught her a lesson.

While (36) she was walking back, she thought about what the flowers mean (37). She promised to keep (38) exploring as a student (39) of life. She wondered why (40) some people never try new things.

She decided to let (41) her heart lead her. It was a great (42) feeling to find the same (43) courage others looked for in big adventures. The forest was a big (44) part of her story now.

Evaluación 4 Vocabulario Nivel B1

Reading Text (Students’ Version): 4

One day, Mr Carter needed help to talk with his team about a project where they had to turn ideas into solutions. The problem was that every person wanted to start work at the same time. He raised his hand and said this might be difficult.

He was an American manager and wanted to show his team that each part of the project was important. They talked about how to work against delays. They looked for a place quiet over there. It was such a busy schedule that they had to begin again a few times.

They hired a few extra developers in case the deadline was near. The most important task each week was to update the company leaders about progress. Then they wondered where the project’s system would fail. Mr Carter reminded each member to do the right thing.

They tested the program until they could hear feedback, so they could improve. One question came during the demo about compatibility. Some thought the software would work for education, others saw it as a way to play games. The government might use it too.

They needed to run tests on a small number of devices. They turned it off when a glitch appeared. They always had to move quickly to fix errors. It felt like they were working at night, but they wanted to live by their goals.

Mr Carter made his point clearly, and all team members believe in him. He will hold a meeting today to bring everyone together.

Reading Text (Teacher’s Version): 4

One day, Mr (1) Carter needed help (2) to talk (3) with his team about a project where (4) they had to turn (5) ideas into solutions. The problem (6) was that every (7) person wanted to start (8) work at the same time. He raised his hand (9) and said this might (10) be difficult.

He was an American (11) manager and wanted to show (12) his team that each part (13) of the project was important. They talked about (14) how to work against (15) delays. They looked for a place (16) quiet over (17) there. It was such (18) a busy schedule that they had to begin again (19) a few (20) times.

They hired a few (20) extra developers in case (21) the deadline was near. The most (22) important task each week (23) was to update the company (24) leaders about progress. Then they wondered where (25) the project’s system (26) would fail. Mr. Carter reminded each (27) member to do the right (28) thing.

They tested the program (29) until they could hear (30) feedback, so (31) they could improve. One question (32) came during (33) the demo about compatibility. Some thought the software would work (34) for education, others saw it as a way to play (35) games. The government (36) might use it too.

They needed to run (37) tests on a small (38) number (39) of devices. They turned it off (40) when a glitch appeared. They always (41) had to move (42) quickly to fix errors. It felt like (43) they were working at night (44), but they wanted to live (45) by their goals.

Mr (1) Carter made his point (46) clearly, and all team members believe (47) in him. He will hold (48) a meeting today (49) to bring (50) everyone together.

Evaluación 5 Vocabulario Nivel B1

Reading Text (Students’ Version): 5

Floods happen next without warning. People prepare before a large storm hits all towns. Over a million residents must leave home. Rising floods flow under doors bringing water into each room. To be ready, families write instructions. A mother keeps her kids in a safe area. The national authority gives money and help. This is not just one story. It affects the young too. The fact is that each month, weather can be different. People have a lot of steps to study. A book catches every eye with tips. Some find a job teaching safety. Every word in the guide matters, though some skip details. Local business owners solve each issue quietly. On the side, volunteers show kind acts. Four rescue teams use their head to scout far away. Dark black skies and a long siren signal danger. Both adults and children need a little practice. Each house must answer yes to drills. After training, they discuss lessons since the last drill. There is no task too long to provide readiness. Volunteers provide service around the clock. A friend coordinates the team. It is important to stay safe.

Reading Text (Teacher’s Version): 5

Floods happen (1) next (2) without (3) warning. People prepare before (4) a large (5) storm hits all (6) towns. Over a million (7) residents must (8) leave home (9). Rising floods flow under (10) doors bringing water (11) into each room (12). To be ready, families write (13) instructions. A mother (14) keeps her kids in a safe area (15). The national (16) authority gives money (17) and help. This is not just one story (18). It affects the young (19) too. The fact (20) is that each month (21), weather can be different (22). People have a lot (23) of steps to study (24). A book (25) catches every eye (26) with tips. Some find a job (27) teaching safety. Every word (28) in the guide matters, though (29) some skip details. Local business (30) owners solve each issue (31) quietly. On the side (32), volunteers show kind (33) acts. Four (34) rescue teams use their head (35) to scout far (36) away. Dark black (37) skies and a long (38) siren signal danger. Both (39) adults and children need a little (40) practice. Each house (41) must answer yes (42) to drills. After (43) training, they discuss lessons since (44) the last drill. There is no task too long (45) to provide (46) readiness. Volunteers provide (47) service (47) around (48) the clock. A friend (49) coordinates the team. It is important (50) to stay safe.

Evaluación 6 Vocabulario Nivel B1

Reading Text (Students’ Version): 6

Father told his son to sit quietly. The bench was away from the busy street until night. The power of silence was strong. After an hour, they saw a game group arrive. They often played outside, yet this match was special. A long line formed by the end of the match.

People stood among friends, and no one had ever felt so happy. They must stand even in bad weather, or they would lose the best seats. However, one member of the crowd asked for water. Fans would pay attention, for sports has its own law.

At nine o’clock, they meet at the car and drove to another city. Almost everyone arrived. Their plans include meals and a tour. They continue traveling even if traffic is slow. They set a time to leave later. The whole community was excited.

They had much to discuss. Each child says their name. There were five helpers once they arrived. A white banner read “Welcome.” At least three teachers were there. The president of the club wanted them to learn from experience. He said this was real teamwork.

They needed to change the schedule. The team practiced every minute to be the best. It took several tries to find the right idea. Every kid used their body to play well. The coach gave information about each role.

After that, there was nothing to worry about. An hour ago, they did not know the plan. Now the children can lead the game themselves.

Reading Text (Teacher’s Version): 6

Father (1) told his son to sit (2) quietly. The bench was away (3) from the busy street until (4) night. The power (5) of silence was strong. After an hour (6), they saw a game (7) group arrive. They often (8) played outside, yet (9) this match was special. A long line (10) formed by the end (11) of the match.

People stood among (12) friends, and no one had ever (13) felt so happy. They must stand (14) even in bad (15) weather, or they would lose (16) the best seats. However (17), one member (18) of the crowd asked for water. Fans would pay (19) attention, for sports has its own law (20).

At nine o’clock, they meet (21) at the car (22) and drove to another city (23). Almost (24) everyone arrived. Their plans include (25) meals and a tour. They continue (26) traveling even if traffic is slow. They set (27) a time to leave later (28). The whole community (29) was excited.

They had much (30) to discuss. Each child says their name (31). There were five (32) helpers once (33) they arrived. A white (34) banner read “Welcome.” At least (35) three teachers were there. The president (36) of the club wanted them to learn (37) from experience. He said this was real (38) teamwork.

They needed to change (39) the schedule. The team (40) practiced every minute (41) to be the best (42). It took several (43) tries to find the right idea (44). Every kid (45) used their body (46) to play well. The coach gave information (47) about each role.

After that, there was nothing (48) to worry about. An hour ago (49), they did not know the plan. Now the children can lead (50) the game themselves.

B1 Evaluación Temas
Capacidad: ¿Qué va a hacer el profesor? 2

Hace las preguntas para evaluar los temas que debe conocer en ese nivel como familia, info personal; aunque reconocemos que no se ha abarcado completamente.

Evaluación: ¿Qué debe poder hacer el estudiante? 2

Ser capaz de responder las preguntas con una respuesta en nivel básico

Preguntas para evaluar los temas
9. Travel and Transportation

  1. How do you usually get to work or school?

  2. What was your last trip like?

  3. Have you ever traveled by plane? Where did you go?

  4. What is your favorite way to travel? Why?

  5. Can you describe your dream vacation?

  6. Have you ever missed a train or a bus? What happened?

  7. What do you prefer: traveling alone or with friends? Why?

  8. How do you prepare for a long trip?

  9. What kind of transportation do you think is the fastest?

  10. Have you ever used a taxi or a ride-sharing app? How was it?

  11. What are some advantages of traveling by train?

  12. How do you feel when you travel to a new country?

  13. What do you like to do during a flight?

  14. Have you ever stayed in a hotel? What do you expect from a good hotel?

  15. Can you explain how to buy a ticket for a bus or train?

  16. What would you take with you on a trip?

  17. What places would you like to visit in your country?

  18. Do you think public transportation is safe in your city?

  19. How can someone save money while traveling?

  20. What are some problems people can have during traveling?

  21. Have you ever lost your luggage? What did you do?

  22. What do you think about traveling by bike or scooter in the city?

  23. How do you usually spend time at the airport?

  24. Can you describe a typical day during a holiday trip?

  25. What tips would you give to someone traveling to a foreign country for the first time?

10. Health and Body

  1. How often do you exercise?

  2. What do you do to stay healthy?

  3. Have you ever had a serious illness? How did you feel?

  4. What is your favorite healthy food?

  5. Can you describe your daily routine for taking care of your body?

  6. Have you ever been to a hospital? Why?

  7. What do you think about smoking and drinking alcohol?

  8. How do you usually relax after a stressful day?

  9. What are some common health problems people have today?

  10. How do you feel when you don’t get enough sleep?

  11. Can you explain why it is important to drink water?

  12. What should people do if they have a cold or flu?

  13. How often do you visit the doctor for a check-up?

  14. Do you prefer home remedies or medicine when you’re sick? Why?

  15. What advice would you give to someone who wants to lose weight?

  16. Can you describe a healthy lifestyle?

  17. Have you ever injured yourself while playing sports?

  18. What do you think about mental health? Is it important?

  19. How can someone stay motivated to exercise regularly?

  20. What is your favorite sport or physical activity?

  21. What foods should you avoid to stay healthy?

  22. How do you protect yourself from getting sick during winter?

  23. Can you explain what you should do in case of an emergency?

  24. What habits can harm your health?

  25. Have you ever had to take medicine for a long time? What was it for?

11. Feelings and Emotions

  1. How do you feel when you are happy?

  2. What makes you feel sad or upset?

  3. Can you describe a time when you were really angry?

  4. How do you usually express your emotions?

  5. What do you do when you feel nervous?

  6. Have you ever been scared of something? What was it?

  7. How do you comfort a friend who is sad?

  8. What are some things that make you feel excited?

  9. Can you explain the difference between being tired and being bored?

  10. How do you feel when you achieve a goal?

  11. What do you do to calm down when you are stressed?

  12. Can you describe how you feel on a typical weekend?

  13. Have you ever felt jealous? Why?

  14. What do you think about showing your emotions in public?

  15. How do you react when someone surprises you?

  16. What emotions do you feel when you listen to music?

  17. Have you ever felt disappointed? What happened?

  18. Can you explain why some people are shy?

  19. How do you handle feeling lonely?

  20. What makes you feel proud of yourself?

  21. How do you feel about making new friends?

  22. What do you think about crying? Is it a sign of weakness or strength?

  23. Have you ever been embarrassed? What happened?

  24. How can someone improve their mood quickly?

  25. What emotions do you associate with the seasons of the year?

12. Technology and Communication

  1. How often do you use the internet?

  2. What is your favorite social media platform? Why?

  3. Can you explain how to send an email?

  4. Have you ever bought something online? What was it?

  5. How do you usually communicate with your friends?

  6. Do you prefer texting or talking on the phone? Why?

  7. What are some advantages of using smartphones?

  8. What problems can technology cause in everyday life?

  9. How do you protect your personal information online?

  10. Can you describe your favorite app or website?

  11. How do you think technology will change in the future?

  12. Have you ever had problems with your computer or phone? What did you do?

  13. What do you think about online learning?

  14. How can technology help in your job or studies?

  15. Do you use video calls to talk to your family or friends?

  16. What are some rules for safe internet use?

  17. How much time do you spend on your phone daily?

  18. Have you ever learned something new using the internet?

  19. Can you explain how to download an app?

  20. What do you think about social media and mental health?

  21. How do you stay focused when there are many distractions online?

  22. What kind of technology do you use at home?

  23. Have you ever created a blog or a social media post? What was it about?

  24. How do you feel when your phone battery is low?

  25. What advice would you give to someone who wants to learn how to use a computer?

13. Entertainment

  1. What is your favorite type of music?

  2. Can you describe a movie you recently watched?

  3. What kind of books do you like to read?

  4. Do you prefer watching movies at home or in the cinema? Why?

  5. What TV shows do you like to watch?

  6. Have you ever been to a concert? How was it?

  7. What do you do when you are bored?

  8. Can you talk about your favorite actor or actress?

  9. What kind of games do you like to play?

  10. Do you prefer watching sports or playing sports? Why?

  11. What is the last song you listened to?

  12. How do you usually spend your weekends?

  13. What do you think makes a good movie or book?

  14. Have you ever met a famous person? What happened?

  15. Can you explain how to play your favorite game?

  16. What hobbies do you have in your free time?

  17. What entertainment do you enjoy with your family?

  18. How often do you go to the theater or concerts?

  19. What is a popular festival or event in your country?

  20. Can you describe a funny or interesting story you remember?

  21. What is the best way to relax after work or school?

  22. How do you feel about reality TV shows?

  23. Have you ever tried a new hobby recently? What was it?

  24. What do you like about cartoons or animated movies?

  25. Can you recommend a good movie or book?

14. Sports and Activities

  1. What sports do you like to watch or play?

  2. How often do you exercise or play sports?

  3. Can you describe your favorite sport?

  4. Have you ever played a team sport? Which one?

  5. What equipment do you need for your favorite sport?

  6. What is the most popular sport in your country?

  7. Can you explain the rules of a sport you like?

  8. How do you feel after doing physical activity?

  9. What sports did you play when you were a child?

  10. Have you ever been to a sports event? What was it like?

  11. What is more important: skill or fitness? Why?

  12. Can you describe a memorable game or match you watched?

  13. What do you think about extreme sports?

  14. Have you ever tried yoga or meditation? How was the experience?

  15. What are some benefits of doing sports regularly?

  16. How do you stay motivated to keep active?

  17. Can you explain how to warm up before exercising?

  18. What sports do you like to do outdoors?

  19. How do sports help people make friends?

  20. Have you ever been injured while doing sports? What happened?

  21. What is your opinion about professional athletes?

  22. What activities do you do when the weather is bad?

  23. Can you describe a sport you would like to learn?

  24. What are some sports that are popular in your city?

  25. How do you prepare for a sports competition or event?

B1 Evaluación Listening
Capacidad: ¿Qué va a hacer el profesor? 3
  1. Opción 1: El profesor coloca un audio de reductores de ruido y el estudiante dice qué dijo el audio y lo traduce al español. (El estudiante dice: She’s tall - Ella es alta)
  2. Opción 2: El docente lee los reductores y el estudiante dice qué dijo el audio y lo traduce al español. (El estudiante dice: She’s tall - Ella es alta)
Evaluación: ¿Qué debe poder hacer el estudiante? 3

Debe poder entender los siguientes audios.

Audios a evaluar

Reductor Preposiciones y Acciones después de la lección Preposiciones

Frase en inglés

Traducción al español

Are the kids playing outside?

¿Están los niños jugando afuera?

Yes, they are playing outside.

Sí, están jugando fuera.

Are your keys at home?

¿Están tus llaves en casa?

No, they are not at home.

No, no están en casa.

Was he behind the door?

¿Estaba él detrás de la puerta?

Yes, he was behind the door.

Sí, estaba detrás de la puerta.

Is the cat on the table?

¿Está el gato sobre la mesa?

Yes, it is on the table.

Sí, está sobre la mesa.

Is the ball under the chair?

¿Está la pelota debajo de la silla?

Yes, it is under the chair.

Sí, está debajo de la silla.

Is the park near your house?

¿Está el parque cerca de tu casa?

Yes, it is near my house.

Sí, está cerca de mi casa.

Is the store between the banks?

¿Está la tienda entre los bancos?

Yes, it is between them.

Sí, está entre ellos.

Is your phone inside the drawer?

¿Está tu celular dentro del cajón?

Yes, it is inside the drawer.

Sí, está dentro del cajón.

Is the car in front of the house?

¿Está el carro frente a la casa?

Yes, it is in front of the house.

Sí, está frente a la casa.

Is she sitting beside you?

¿Está ella sentada a tu lado?

Yes, she is sitting beside me.

Sí, está sentada a mi lado.

Where is the book?

¿Dónde está el libro?

It is in the bag.

Está en la bolsa.

Reductor Acciones 4

Frase en inglés

Traducción al español

Tipo de oración

Tiempo

Verbo Clave

Did you hear the noise?

¿Escuchaste el ruido?

Pregunta Positiva

Pasado simple

hear

Yes, I heard it.

Sí, lo escuché.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado simple

hear

Did she forget her bag?

¿Olvidó ella su bolso?

Pregunta Positiva

Pasado simple

forget

Yes, she forgot it.

Sí, lo olvidó.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado simple

forget

I pay every week.

Yo pago cada semana.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

pay

He paid yesterday.

Él pagó ayer.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado simple

pay

Did he stand at the door?

¿Estuvo él de pie en la puerta?

Pregunta Positiva

Pasado simple

stand

Yes, he stood there.

Sí, estuvo allí.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado simple

stand

They fight all the time.

Ellos pelean todo el tiempo.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

fight

They fought last night.

Ellos pelearon anoche.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado simple

fight

I think you are right.

Creo que tienes razón.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

think

I thought about that.

Pensé en eso.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado simple

think

He lost his keys.

Él perdió sus llaves.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado simple

lose

Did she catch the ball?

¿Ella atrapó la pelota?

Pregunta Positiva

Pasado simple

catch

Yes, she caught it.

Sí, la atrapó.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado simple

catch

I laid the book on the table.

Puse el libro sobre la mesa.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado simple

lay

She lent me a pencil.

Ella me prestó un lápiz.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado simple

lend

He has proven his idea.

Él ha probado su idea.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente perfecto

prove

She burned the toast.

Ella quemó el pan tostado.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado simple

burn

They dealt with the problem.

Ellos trataron el problema.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado simple

deal

Did the balloon burst?

¿Explotó el globo?

Pregunta Positiva

Pasado simple

burst

Yes, it burst.

Sí, explotó.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado simple

burst

Reductor Acciones 5 después de la lección Mi Rutina Diaria para Aprender Inglés con Choco Inglés (la q está después de Tema 10. Salud y Cuerpo)

Frase en inglés

Traducción al español

Verbo Clave

Tom wants to be a teacher.

Tom quiere ser maestro.

be

He was at a school last week to observe the students but they were not in class.

Estuvo en una escuela la semana pasada para observar a los estudiantes, pero no estaban en clase.

be

He’s been studying hard since then, but he hasn’t been teaching yet.

Ha estado estudiando mucho desde entonces, pero aún no ha sido profesor.

be

Anna likes to have pets.

A Anna le gusta tener mascotas.

have

She had a dog once, but it ran away.

Una vez tuvo un perro, pero se escapó.

She’s had other pets, but none were as loyal.

Ha tenido otras mascotas, pero ninguna ha sido tan leal.

Mike loves to do puzzles.

A Mike le encanta hacer rompecabezas.

do

Last night, he did a 1,000-piece puzzle.

Anoche, hizo uno de 1,000 piezas.

He’s done many, but this one took forever.

Ha hecho muchos, pero este le llevó una eternidad.

Lucy wants to go on a trip.

Lucy quiere ir de viaje.

go

She went to Paris last year.

Fue a París el año pasado.

Since then, she’s gone on many adventures.

Desde entonces, ha ido a muchas aventuras.

Leo wants to say something important.

Leo quiere decir algo importante.

say

He said it yesterday at the meeting.

Lo dijo ayer en la reunión.

He’s said it many times now.

Lo ha dicho muchas veces ahora.

Sara hopes to get good grades.

Sara espera obtener buenas calificaciones.

get

She got an A in math.

Obtuvo una A en matemáticas.

She’s gotten more confident with each test.

Ha obtenido mejores resultados con cada examen.

Jake tries to make pizza.

Jake intenta hacer pizza.

make

He made one last night, but it burned.

Hizo una anoche, pero se quemó.

He’s made better ones before.

Ha hecho mejores antes.

Sam loves to take naps.

A Sam le encanta tomar siestas.

take

Yesterday, he took a long one.

Ayer, tomó una larga.

He’s taken so many naps that he feels like a cat.

Ha tomado tantas siestas que se siente como un gato.

Juan doesn't like to see his mother-in-law. She's always mad at him.

A Juan no le gusta ver a su suegra. Ella siempre está enojada con él.

see

The other day when she saw him in the kitchen, she tried to burn him.

El otro día, cuando lo vio en la cocina, intentó quemarlo.

He hasn't seen her since then

No la ha visto desde entonces.

Sandra tries to come early to class.

Sandra intenta llegar temprano a clase.

come

Last week, she came too late.

La semana pasada, llegó demasiado tarde.

She’s come on time ever since.

Ha llegado a tiempo desde entonces.

Jack wants to know everything.

Jack quiere saberlo todo.

know

Last week, he knew all the answers in trivia.

La semana pasada, supo todas las respuestas en un juego de trivia.

He’s known as the smart guy ever since.

Ha sabido responder a todo desde entonces.

Mary likes to think before acting.

A Mary le gusta pensar antes de actuar.

think

She thought long and hard about her decision.

Pensó mucho y detenidamente sobre su decisión.

She’s thought about it every day since.

Ha pensado en ello todos los días desde entonces.

Tim tries to give compliments.

Tim intenta dar cumplidos.

give

He gave one to his teacher yesterday.

Le dio uno a su maestra ayer.

He’s given them to many people lately.

Ha dado muchos a varias personas últimamente.

Sue hopes to find her keys.

Sue espera encontrar sus llaves.

find

She found them under the couch last night.

Las encontró debajo del sofá anoche.

She’s found things in stranger places before.

Ha encontrado cosas en lugares más extraños antes.

Sarah wants to tell a secret.

Sarah quiere contar un secreto.

tell

She told it to her best friend.

Se lo contó a su mejor amiga.

She’s told many more since then.

Ha contado muchos más desde entonces.

John wants to become an actor.

John quiere convertirse en actor.

become

He became interested after watching a play.

Se convirtió en un aficionado después de ver una obra de teatro.

He’s become more confident in performing.

Se ha convertido en un actor más seguro al actuar.

Mark tries to leave on time.

Mark intenta salir a tiempo.

leave

He left late yesterday, though.

Sin embargo, ayer salió tarde.

He’s left early before but always gets delayed.

Ha salido temprano antes, pero siempre se retrasa.

Jane wants to feel relaxed.

Jane quiere sentirse relajada.

feel

She felt tired last night.

Se sintió cansada anoche.

She’s felt better today after some rest.

Se ha sentido mejor hoy después de descansar un poco.

Tom always puts his keys on the table.

Tom siempre pone sus llaves sobre la mesa.

put

Yesterday, he put them in his bag by mistake.

Ayer, las puso en su bolso por error.

He has put them in so many places that now he’s careful where to leave them.

Las ha puesto en tantos lugares que ahora tiene cuidado dónde dejarlas.

Jane tries to keep secrets.

Jane intenta guardar secretos.

keep

Last time, she kept one for a week.

La última vez, guardó uno durante una semana.

She’s kept more since then.

Ha guardado más desde entonces.

Reductor Acciones 6 después de la lección Reductor Temas F.I.4

Frase en inglés

Traducción al español

Verbo Clave

He wants success.

Él quiere éxito.

want

I wanted to go.

Yo quise ir.

They have wanted many things.

Ellos han querido muchas cosas.

We use tools.

Nosotros usamos herramientas.

use

She used a computer.

Ella usó una computadora.

You have used this before.

Tú has usado esto antes.

They need help.

Ellos necesitan ayuda.

need

We needed time.

Nosotros necesitamos tiempo.

He has needed assistance.

Él ha necesitado asistencia.

He calls friends.

Él llama a amigos.

call

We called home.

Nosotros llamamos a casa.

They have called often.

Ellos han llamado a menudo.

He continues working.

Él continúa trabajando.

work

We continued despite obstacles.

Nosotros continuamos a pesar de los obstáculos.

They have continued learning.

Ellos han continuado aprendiendo.

Mia likes chocolate.

A Mia le gusta el chocolate.

like

She liked the cake yesterday.

Le gustó el pastel ayer.

She has liked sweets since childhood.

Le han gustado los dulces desde la infancia.

I ask questions.

Hago preguntas.

ask

She asked yesterday.

Ella preguntó ayer.

They have asked often.

Ellos han preguntado a menudo.

They always help their neighbors.

Siempre ayudan a sus vecinos.

help

Last week, they helped them move.

La semana pasada, los ayudaron a mudarse.

They have helped many people before.

Han ayudado a muchas personas antes.

We play sports.

Nosotros jugamos deportes.

play

You played yesterday.

Tú jugaste ayer.

He has played often.

Él ha jugado a menudo.

They move quickly.

Ellos se mueven rápido.

move

She moved houses.

Ella se mudó de casa.

We have moved furniture.

Nosotros hemos movido muebles.

You live here.

Tú vives aquí.

live

They lived abroad.

Ellos vivieron en el extranjero.

We have lived in cities.

Nosotros hemos vivido en ciudades.

We watch movies every Friday.

Vemos películas todos los viernes.

watch

We watched a comedy last night.

Vimos una comedia anoche.

We have watched that one before.

Ya hemos visto esa antes.

He starts work at 8 a.m.

Empieza a trabajar a las 8 a.m.

start

He started late yesterday.

Ayer empezó tarde.

He has started new routines recently.

Ha empezado nuevas rutinas recientemente.

They talk daily.

Ellos hablan a diario.

talk

We talked yesterday.

Nosotros hablamos ayer.

She has talked for hours.

Ella ha hablado durante horas.

She listens to podcasts daily.

Ella escucha pódcast todos los días.

listen

She listened to a new one this morning.

Esta mañana escuchó uno nuevo.

She has listened to many episodes.

Ha escuchado muchos episodios.

He turns off the lights before bed.

Apaga las luces antes de dormir.

turn

He turned them off earlier.

Las apagó más temprano.

He has turned them off already.

Ya las ha apagado.

They finish work at 6.

Terminan el trabajo a las 6.

finish

They finished early yesterday.

Ayer terminaron temprano.

They have finished all their tasks.

Han terminado todas sus tareas.

You open doors.

Tú abres puertas.

open

We opened the window.

Nosotros abrimos la ventana.

They have opened many books.

Ellos han abierto muchos libros.

I always close the windows at night.

Siempre cierro las ventanas por la noche.

close

I closed them yesterday.

Las cerré ayer.

I have closed them every night this week.

Las he cerrado todas las noches esta semana.

They move quickly.

Ellos se mueven rápido.

move

She moved houses.

Ella se mudó de casa.

We have moved furniture.

Nosotros hemos movido muebles.

Reductor Temas F.I.4 después de la lección Manténte enfocado en la meta

Frase en inglés

Traducción al español

Tipo reducción

Tiempo

Verbo Clave

How do you get to work?

¿Cómo llegas al trabajo?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Do

I take the bus.

Yo tomo el autobús.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Take

How long does it take to get there?

¿Cuánto tiempo toma llegar allí?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Does, Take

It takes 30 minutes.

Toma 30 minutos.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Takes

Book a ticket online.

Reserva un boleto en línea.

Afirmación Positiva

Imperativo

Book

Pay at the counter.

Paga en el mostrador.

Afirmación Positiva

Imperativo

Pay

Is my reservation confirmed?

¿Está confirmada mi reserva?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Is

Yes, my reservation is confirmed.

Sí, mi reserva está confirmada.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Is

Can I cancel my ticket?

¿Puedo cancelar mi boleto?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Can

Yes, you can cancel your ticket.

Sí, puedes cancelar tu boleto.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Can

When does the next train leave?

¿Cuándo sale el próximo tren?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Does, Leave

The next train leaves at 5 PM.

El próximo tren sale a las 5 PM.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Leaves

When is the next train?

¿Cuándo es el próximo tren?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Is

The next train is at 7 PM.

El próximo tren es a las 7 PM.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Is

What time does the bus leave?

¿A qué hora sale el autobús?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Does, Leave

The bus leaves at 8 AM.

El autobús sale a las 8 AM.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Leaves

What time does the bus arrive?

¿A qué hora llega el autobús?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Does, Arrive

The bus arrives at 6 o'clock.

El autobús llega a las 6 en punto.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Arrives

The check-in desk is on the left.

El mostrador de facturación está a la izquierda.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Is

The arrivals hall is on the second floor.

La sala de llegadas está en el segundo piso.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Is

Reductor TH Sounds (Repaso) después de la lección Historia 3: Th al final - Fundamentación Indispensable

Frase en inglés

Traducción al español

Tipo reducción

Tiempo Verbo Clave

Fernando, Michael and Pedro were friends.

Fernando, Michael y Pedro eran amigos.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

It was a sunny Thursday.

Era un jueves soleado.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

They decided to go to the park.

Ellos decidieron ir al parque.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

There were many fun things to do.

Había muchas cosas divertidas para hacer.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

These children were playing and laughing.

Estos niños estaban jugando y riendo.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado continuo

They were having a great time.

Ellos la estaban pasando muy bien.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado continuo

The three friends walked through the park.

Los tres amigos caminaron por el parque.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

They thought about what to do next.

Pensaron en qué hacer después.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

Hey, I think it’s getting really hot.

Oye, creo que se está poniendo muy caliente.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente continuo

Let’s get some ice cream.

Vamos por un helado.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

That’s a great idea!

¡Esa es una gran idea!

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

The others said.

Los otros dijeron.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

They looked at those colorful ice cream flavors.

Miraron esos sabores coloridos de helado.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

They couldn’t decide which one to choose.

No pudieron decidir cuál elegir.

Afirmación Negativa

Pasado

Then, one of them said.

Entonces, uno de ellos dijo.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

Let’s get them all!

¡Vamos a cogerlos todos!

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

They bought a few flavors.

Compraron algunos sabores.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

They thanked the vendor.

Agradecieron al vendedor.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

Though it was hot, they were happy.

Aunque hacía calor, estaban felices.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

They knew that days like this were worth a thousand memories.

Sabían que días como este valían mil recuerdos.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

Tom was sad.

Tom estaba triste.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

His mother and father were always busy.

Su madre y su padre siempre estaban ocupados.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

The other day, his brother Jack said.

El otro día, su hermano Jack dijo.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

Let's go outside together!

¡Vamos afuera juntos!

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

The weather is nice.

El clima está agradable.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Tom replied.

Tom respondió.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

I'd rather stay inside.

Prefiero quedarme adentro.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

There's nothing fun out there.

No hay nada divertido allá afuera.

Afirmación Negativa

Presente

Jack smiled.

Jack sonrió.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

Brother, that's not true!

¡Hermano, eso no es cierto!

Afirmación Negativa

Presente

There's something fun everywhere if you look.

Hay algo divertido en todas partes si miras.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Come on, I'll show you.

Vamos, te lo mostraré.

Afirmación Positiva

Futuro con "will"

Tom thought for a moment.

Tom pensó por un momento.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

Well... okay.

Bueno... está bien.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

It's better than doing nothing.

Es mejor que no hacer nada.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

When they got home, their parents were there.

Cuando llegaron a casa, sus padres estaban allí.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

Did you do anything fun today?

¿Hiciste algo divertido hoy?

Pregunta Positiva

Pasado

Asked their mother.

Preguntó su madre.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

We did everything!

¡Hicimos de todo!

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

Tom said happily.

Dijo Tom felizmente.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

We played in the park.

Jugamos en el parque.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

Although I didn't want to go at first.

Aunque no quería ir al principio.

Afirmación Negativa

Pasado

I'm glad we did.

Me alegra que lo hayamos hecho.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Their father smiled.

Su padre sonrió.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

That's great!

¡Eso es genial!

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Whether you play inside or out.

Ya sea que juegues adentro o afuera.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

It's always good to do things together.

Siempre es bueno hacer cosas juntos.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

From that day on, Tom knew that without his family, life wouldn't be as fun.

Desde ese día, Tom supo que sin su familia, la vida no sería tan divertida.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

He learned that there was always something to enjoy.

Aprendió que siempre había algo para disfrutar.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

No matter what.

No importa qué.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

With both hands, María stepped into the bath.

Con ambas manos, María entró en la bañera.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

She was ready to begin her daily ritual.

Estaba lista para comenzar su ritual diario.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

The path she walked each morning led her to reflect on the Earth and its wonders.

El camino que recorría cada mañana la llevaba a reflexionar sobre la Tierra y sus maravillas.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

This month marked a year since the birth of her daughter.

Este mes marcó un año desde el nacimiento de su hija.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

It was a joyous occasion.

Fue una ocasión feliz.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

It had forever changed her perspective on life and death.

Había cambiado para siempre su perspectiva sobre la vida y la muerte.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado perfecto

Faith had always been important to María.

La fe siempre había sido importante para María.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado perfecto

Now it took on new meaning.

Ahora tenía un nuevo significado.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

She witnessed the growth of her child.

Ella fue testigo del crecimiento de su hija.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

The worth of every moment became clearer.

El valor de cada momento se volvió más claro.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

She treasured her family's health above all else.

Atesoraba la salud de su familia por encima de todo.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

As she dried off, María pondered the truth of her existence.

Mientras se secaba, María reflexionó sobre la verdad de su existencia.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

She realized that wealth wasn't just about money.

Se dio cuenta de que la riqueza no se trataba solo de dinero.

Afirmación Negativa

Pasado

It was about the richness of experiences and relationships.

Se trataba de la riqueza de las experiencias y las relaciones.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

With this understanding came a newfound strength.

Con esta comprensión llegó una nueva fuerza.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

It would guide her through whatever challenges lay ahead.

La guiaría a través de cualquier desafío que estuviera por venir.

Afirmación Positiva

Futuro con "would"

Reductor F.I.5 Topics después de la lección 🧠 Modals en pasado: Can’t have &amp; Needn’t have

Frase en inglés

Traducción al español

Tipo reducción

Tiempo

Will you have been waiting long?

¿Habrás estado esperando mucho?

Pregunta Positiva

Future Perfect Continuous

Yes, I will have been waiting for an hour.

Sí, habré estado esperando una hora.

Afirmación Positiva

Future Perfect Continuous

Will they have been working all day?

¿Habrán estado trabajando todo el día?

Pregunta Positiva

Future Perfect Continuous

Yes, they will have been working since morning.

Sí, habrán estado trabajando desde la mañana.

Afirmación Positiva

Future Perfect Continuous

How long will she have been sleeping?

¿Cuánto tiempo habrá estado durmiendo ella?

Pregunta Positiva

Future Perfect Continuous

She will have been sleeping for three hours.

Ella habrá estado durmiendo por tres horas.

Afirmación Positiva

Future Perfect Continuous

How long will you have been studying?

¿Cuánto tiempo habrás estado estudiando?

Pregunta Positiva

Future Perfect Continuous

I will have been studying for two hours.

Habré estado estudiando por dos horas.

Afirmación Positiva

Future Perfect Continuous

Should I have studied more?

¿Debería haber estudiado más?

Pregunta Positiva

Modal Perfect

Yes, you should have studied more.

Sí, deberías haber estudiado más.

Afirmación Positiva

Modal Perfect

Should she have called you?

¿Debería ella haberte llamado?

Pregunta Positiva

Modal Perfect

No, she should not have called me.

No, ella no debería haberme llamado.

Afirmación Negativa

Modal Perfect

Could you have won the game?

¿Podrías haber ganado el juego?

Pregunta Positiva

Modal Perfect

No, I could not have won the game.

No, no podría haber ganado el juego.

Afirmación Negativa

Modal Perfect

Could he have finished the work?

¿Podría él haber terminado el trabajo?

Pregunta Positiva

Modal Perfect

Yes, he could have finished the work.

Sí, él podría haber terminado el trabajo.

Afirmación Positiva

Modal Perfect

Might he have forgotten the keys?

¿Podría él haber olvidado las llaves?

Pregunta Positiva

Modal Perfect

Yes, he might have forgotten the keys.

Sí, él podría haber olvidado las llaves.

Afirmación Positiva

Modal Perfect

Might we have missed the bus?

¿Podríamos haber perdido el bus?

Pregunta Positiva

Modal Perfect

No, we might not have missed the bus.

No, puede que no hayamos perdido el bus.

Negación Positiva

Modal Perfect

Reductor Facilísimo M1 después lección Facilísimo Módulo 1

English:

Reductor ComQueTag+Cond (Complex question tags, Conditionals, 2nd and 3rd) después de la lección Curiosidades M1

Frase en inglés

Traducción al español

Tema

You wouldn't have recognized her after all these years, would you?

No la habrías reconocido después de todos estos años, ¿verdad?

Complex Question Tags

He hardly ever complains about work, does he?

Casi nunca se queja del trabajo, ¿verdad?

Complex Question Tags

She should have informed us earlier, shouldn’t she?

Ella debió habernos informado antes, ¿no?

Complex Question Tags

Nobody expected him to resign, did they?

Nadie esperaba que renunciara, ¿verdad?

Complex Question Tags

They had never been to Japan before, had they?

Nunca habían estado en Japón antes, ¿cierto?

Complex Question Tags

You won’t be late again, will you?

No llegarás tarde otra vez, ¿cierto?

Complex Question Tags

Let’s not forget to send the email, shall we?

No olvidemos enviar el correo, ¿de acuerdo?

Complex Question Tags

Everything went smoothly, didn’t it?

Todo salió sin problemas, ¿verdad?

Complex Question Tags

If she studied more consistently, she would get better results.

Si ella estudiara más constantemente, obtendría mejores resultados.

2nd Conditional

If they weren’t so disorganized, the project would be finished by now.

Si no fueran tan desorganizados, el proyecto ya estaría terminado.

2nd Conditional

If I were you, I’d talk to the manager directly.

Si yo fuera tú, hablaría directamente con el gerente.

2nd Conditional

She wouldn’t be so stressed if she took regular breaks.

Ella no estaría tan estresada si tomara descansos regularmente.

2nd Conditional

We would have caught the train if we hadn’t left so late.

Habríamos alcanzado el tren si no hubiéramos salido tan tarde.

3rd Conditional

If I had known about the meeting, I would have prepared a report.

Si hubiera sabido de la reunión, habría preparado un informe.

3rd Conditional

I wouldn’t have missed the deadline if I had set a reminder.

No habría perdido la fecha límite si hubiera puesto un recordatorio.

3rd Conditional

If we had taken the other route, we wouldn’t have been stuck in traffic.

Si hubiéramos tomado la otra ruta, no estaríamos atrapados en el tráfico.

3rd Conditional

If he had practiced more, he could have passed the audition.

Si él hubiera practicado más, podría haber pasado la audición.

3rd Conditional

Reductor Connec+FutuCont (Connecting words, Future continuous) después de la lección Parte 3 - Módulo 1 - Historia #2 Jonny en un callejón sin salida

Frase en inglés

Traducción al español

Tema

Why did she resign, although she loved her job? Because she felt undervalued despite her dedication.

¿Por qué renunció, aunque amaba su trabajo? Porque se sentía poco valorada a pesar de su dedicación.

Connecting words

He took the day off due to his high fever.

Se tomó el día libre debido a su fiebre alta.

Connecting words

They decided to postpone the trip since the weather was getting worse.

Decidieron posponer el viaje ya que el clima estaba empeorando.

Connecting words

Even though the evidence was clear, the jury found him not guilty.

Aunque la evidencia era clara, el jurado lo declaró inocente.

Connecting words

In spite of being exhausted, she continued working until midnight.

A pesar de estar exhausta, siguió trabajando hasta la medianoche.

Connecting words

He failed the exam because he hadn't revised the grammar properly.

Reprobó el examen porque no había repasado la gramática adecuadamente.

Connecting words

While she enjoys living in the city, she often misses the quiet of the countryside.

Aunque disfruta vivir en la ciudad, a menudo extraña la tranquilidad del campo.

Connecting words

As a result of the pandemic, many companies implemented remote work permanently.

Como resultado de la pandemia, muchas empresas implementaron el trabajo remoto de forma permanente.

Connecting words

She didn’t get the scholarship; nevertheless, she decided to study abroad.

No obtuvo la beca; sin embargo, decidió estudiar en el extranjero.

Connecting words

On the one hand, the job pays well. On the other hand, it requires long hours.

Por un lado, el trabajo paga bien. Por otro lado, requiere muchas horas.

Connecting words

This time next week, I’ll be presenting the project to the entire board.

A esta hora la próxima semana, estaré presentando el proyecto ante toda la junta.

Future Continuous

Will you be using the printer later? I need to make some copies.

¿Estarás usando la impresora más tarde? Necesito hacer unas copias.

Future Continuous

Don’t call me at 10 PM; I’ll be watching the season finale.

No me llames a las 10 PM; estaré viendo el final de temporada.

Future Continuous

By the end of the year, we’ll be living in a different country.

Para finales del año, estaremos viviendo en otro país.

Future Continuous

Will they be attending the training session tomorrow morning?

¿Asistirán a la sesión de capacitación mañana por la mañana?

Future Continuous

She won’t be joining us for dinner because she’ll be attending a conference.

Ella no se unirá a nosotros para cenar porque estará asistiendo a una conferencia.

Future Continuous

At this time tomorrow, you’ll be flying over the Atlantic Ocean.

A esta hora mañana, estarás volando sobre el Océano Atlántico.

Future Continuous

What will you be doing while we’re on vacation?

¿Qué estarás haciendo mientras estemos de vacaciones?

Future Continuous

I’ll be working from home the entire week due to the renovations at the office.

Estaré trabajando desde casa toda la semana debido a las renovaciones en la oficina.

Future Continuous

Reductor Paradigma 1 después de la lección Parte 3 - Módulo 1 - Historia #2 Jonny en un callejón sin salida

Frase en inglés

Traducción al español

Tipo reducción

Tiempo

Verbo Clave

Are you feeling under the weather?

¿Te sientes mal?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Feel

Yes, I am feeling under the weather.

Sí, me siento mal.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Feel

Did you bite the bullet yesterday?

¿Tomaste la decisión difícil ayer?

Pregunta Positiva

Pasado

Bite

Yes, I bit the bullet and did it.

Sí, tomé la decisión y lo hice.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

Bite

Are you sweating bullets?

¿Estás sudando mucho?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Sweat

No, I am not sweating bullets.

No, no estoy sudando mucho.

Afirmación Negativa

Presente

Sweat

When did you get off work?

¿Cuándo saliste del trabajo?

Pregunta Positiva

Pasado

Get

I got off work at six o'clock.

Salí del trabajo a las seis.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

Get

Were you mugged last night?

¿Te asaltaron anoche?

Pregunta Positiva

Pasado

Mug

No, I was not mugged last night.

No, no me asaltaron anoche.

Afirmación Negativa

Pasado

Mug

Is the thief dangerous?

¿El ladrón es peligroso?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Be

Yes, the thief is dangerous.

Sí, el ladrón es peligroso.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Be

Are you sick today?

¿Estás enfermo hoy?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Be

Yes, I am sick today.

Sí, estoy enfermo hoy.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Be

Do you think this is dangerous?

¿Crees que esto es peligroso?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Think

Yes, I think it is dangerous.

Sí, creo que es peligroso.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Think

Why are you late?

¿Por qué llegaste tarde?

Pregunta Positiva

Pasado

Be

Because the bus was late.

Porque el bus llegó tarde.

Afirmación Negativa

Pasado

Be

Why do you study English?

¿Por qué estudias inglés?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Study

Because I want to travel.

Porque quiero viajar.

Respuesta

Presente

Want

Would you like some coffee?

¿Te gustaría un poco de café?

Pregunta Positiva

Condicional

Would

Yes, I would like some coffee.

Sí, me gustaría un poco de café.

Afirmación Positiva

Condicional

Would

Would you help me with this?

¿Me ayudarías con esto?

Pregunta Positiva

Condicional

Would

Yes, I would help you.

Sí, te ayudaría.

Afirmación Positiva

Condicional

Would

Reductor Idioms/Slangs 1 después de la lección + MÁS SLANGS

Frase en inglés

Traducción al español

Tipo reducción

Tiempo

Is "Out of sight, out of mind" true?

¿Es cierto el dicho "Ojos que no ven, corazón que no siente"? (Este refrán se refiere a que tendemos a olvidar lo que no vemos constantemente)

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Yes, it is true.

Sí, es cierto.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Is going to the party out of the question?

¿Está descartado ir a la fiesta?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

No, it is not out of the question.

No, no está descartado.

Afirmación Negativa

Presente

Is the store out of the way?

¿La tienda queda lejos/apartada?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Yes, it is out of the way.

Sí, queda lejos/apartada.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Is this car out of my budget?

¿Este carro está fuera de mi presupuesto?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Yes, it is out of my budget.

Sí, está fuera de mi presupuesto.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Is this food out of this world?

¿Esta comida está increíble/buenísima?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Yes, this food is out of this world.

Sí, esta comida está increíble.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Is she out of the picture now?

¿Ya no cuenta con ella?/¿Ya no está en la jugada? (es decir, ya no es tomada en cuenta)

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Yes, she is out of the picture.

Sí, ya no cuenta/ya no está en la jugada.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Are you out of practice in swimming?

¿Hace rato que no practicas natación?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Yes, I am out of practice.

Sí, hace rato que no practico.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Are you out of respect for your teacher?

¿Lo haces por respeto a tu profesor?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Yes, I am out of respect.

Sí, lo hago por respeto.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Did you hit the books last night?

¿Te pusiste a estudiar anoche?

Pregunta Positiva

Pasado

Yes, I hit the books.

Sí, me puse a estudiar.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

Did the cat appear out of nowhere?

¿Apareció el gato de la nada?

Pregunta Positiva

Pasado

Yes, the cat appeared out of nowhere.

Sí, el gato apareció de la nada.

Afirmación Positiva

Pasado

Reductor Facilísimo M2 después lección Facilísimo Módulo 2

Frase en inglés

Traducción al español

Tipo reducción

Tiempo Verbo Clave

Are you kidding me?

¿Me estás tomando el pelo?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente continuo

No, I’m serious.

No, hablo en serio.

Afirmación Negativa

Presente simple

Do you wanna eat pizza?

¿Quieres comer pizza?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Yes, I wanna eat pizza.

Sí, quiero comer pizza.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

What do you worry about?

¿Por qué te preocupas?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente simple

I worry about my exams.

Me preocupo por mis exámenes.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente simple

Does he worry too much?

¿Él se preocupa demasiado?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente simple

No, he doesn't worry a lot.

No, él no se preocupa mucho.

Afirmación Negativa

Presente simple

What does she study?

¿Qué estudia ella?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente simple

She studies medicine.

Ella estudia medicina.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente simple

Is this his book?

¿Este es su libro? (de él)

Pregunta Positiva

Presente simple

Yes, it’s his book.

Sí, es su libro.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente simple

Is that her phone?

¿Ese es su teléfono? (de ella)

Pregunta Positiva

Presente simple

No, that’s not her phone.

No, ese no es su teléfono.

Afirmación Negativa

Presente simple

Are you kidding me?

¿Estás bromeando conmigo?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente continuo

No, I’m not kidding you.

No, no estoy bromeando contigo.

Afirmación Negativa

Presente continuo

Do you wanna go outside?

¿Quieres salir?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Yes, I wanna go outside.

Sí, quiero salir.

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

What are his worries?

¿Cuáles son sus preocupaciones?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente simple

His worries are about school.

Sus preocupaciones son sobre la escuela.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente simple

What does she study?

¿Qué estudia ella?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente simple

She studies English.

Ella estudia inglés.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente simple

Is this his pencil?

¿Este es su lápiz? (de él)

Pregunta Positiva

Presente simple

Yes, it’s his pencil.

Sí, es su lápiz.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente simple

Is that her notebook?

¿Ese es su cuaderno? (de ella)

Pregunta Positiva

Presente simple

No, it’s not her notebook.

No, no es su cuaderno.

Afirmación Negativa

Presente simple

Reductor Modals B1 (Modals – must/can’t deduction, Modals – might, may, will, probably, Modals – should have/might have/etc, Modals – must/have to) después de la lección M2 MIRA ESTE VIDEO ANTES DE VER LA HISTORIA

Frase en inglés

Traducción al español

Tema

She must be exhausted after that long hike.

Ella debe estar agotada después de esa larga caminata.

must/can’t deduction

He can’t be serious about quitting his job.

No puede estar hablando en serio sobre renunciar a su trabajo.

must/can’t deduction

You must have left your keys at the café.

Debes haber dejado tus llaves en el café.

must/can’t deduction

They can’t have finished already—it’s too soon.

No pueden haber terminado ya; es demasiado pronto.

must/can’t deduction

That must be his sister; they look exactly alike.

Esa debe ser su hermana; se parecen muchísimo.

must/can’t deduction

She can’t be older than 25—she looks really young.

No puede tener más de 25 años; se ve muy joven.

must/can’t deduction

You must be joking. There’s no way we’re late!

Debes estar bromeando. ¡No hay forma de que lleguemos tarde!

must/can’t deduction

He must be the new manager everyone is talking about.

Él debe ser el nuevo gerente del que todos hablan.

must/can’t deduction

She might come to the meeting if she finishes early.

Ella podría venir a la reunión si termina temprano.

might/may/will/probably

They may not agree with our proposal.

Puede que no estén de acuerdo con nuestra propuesta.

might/may/will/probably

He will probably arrive late—he’s always stuck in traffic.

Probablemente llegue tarde; siempre está atrapado en el tráfico.

might/may/will/probably

We might have to cancel the trip due to bad weather.

Puede que tengamos que cancelar el viaje por mal clima.

might/may/will/probably

It may take a while to get the results.

Puede que tarde un poco en llegar los resultados.

might/may/will/probably

You’ll probably enjoy the show—it has great reviews.

Probablemente disfrutes del espectáculo; tiene excelentes reseñas.

might/may/will/probably

He might not pass the exam if he doesn’t study harder.

Puede que no apruebe el examen si no estudia más.

might/may/will/probably

She may already know about the surprise.

Puede que ella ya sepa sobre la sorpresa.

might/may/will/probably

You should have told me earlier.

Deberías haberme dicho antes.

should have/might have/etc

He might have forgotten our appointment.

Puede que haya olvidado nuestra cita.

should have/might have/etc

They could have taken the wrong train.

Podrían haber tomado el tren equivocado.

should have/might have/etc

I shouldn’t have trusted him so easily.

No debería haber confiado en él tan fácilmente.

should have/might have/etc

She might not have seen your message.

Puede que no haya visto tu mensaje.

should have/might have/etc

We should have planned the event better.

Deberíamos haber planeado mejor el evento.

should have/might have/etc

He could have won if he had trained harder.

Podría haber ganado si hubiera entrenado más.

should have/might have/etc

You might have misunderstood what she said.

Puede que hayas malinterpretado lo que ella dijo.

should have/might have/etc

You must wear a helmet when riding a bike.

Debes usar casco cuando montas bicicleta.

must/have to

She has to finish the report by tomorrow.

Ella tiene que terminar el informe para mañana.

must/have to

We must be respectful during the meeting.

Debemos ser respetuosos durante la reunión.

must/have to

They have to follow the safety regulations at all times.

Ellos tienen que seguir las normas de seguridad en todo momento.

must/have to

You must not smoke inside the building.

No debes fumar dentro del edificio.

must/have to

He has to attend the conference next week.

Él tiene que asistir a la conferencia la próxima semana.

must/have to

We must leave early to catch the train.

Debemos salir temprano para alcanzar el tren.

must/have to

She has to take the medicine twice a day.

Ella tiene que tomar la medicina dos veces al día.

must/have to

You must keep your ID visible at all times.

Debes mantener tu identificación visible en todo momento.

must/have to

They have to complete the application form by Friday.

Ellos tienen que completar el formulario de inscripción para el viernes.

must/have to

Reductor PasCont+PasSim+PasTenResponse (Past continuous, Past perfect, Past simple, Past tense responses) después de la lección Técnica Writing

Inglés

Español

Tiempo Verbal

Did you attend the seminar last week?

¿Asististe al seminario la semana pasada?

Past Simple

Did she quit her job so suddenly?

¿Por qué renunció a su trabajo tan de repente?

Past Simple

Did she tell me the whole story?

No, ella no me contó toda la historia.

Past Tense Responses

Did we enjoy the trip, even though it rained a lot?

Sí, disfrutamos el viaje, aunque llovió mucho.

Past Tense Responses

He didn’t answer my call, so I sent him a message.

No respondió mi llamada, así que le envié un mensaje.

Past Simple

I didn’t expect the movie to be so emotional.

No esperaba que la película fuera tan emotiva.

Past Simple

She wasn’t paying attention when the teacher explained the assignment.

Ella no estaba prestando atención cuando el profesor explicó la tarea.

Past Continuous

I wasn’t sleeping well because the neighbors were making noise all night.

No estaba durmiendo bien porque los vecinos hacían ruido toda la noche.

Past Continuous

No, I wasn’t listening because I was distracted by my phone.

No, no estaba escuchando porque estaba distraído con mi teléfono.

Past Tense Responses

No, they weren’t working on the project last night.

No, no estaban trabajando en el proyecto anoche.

Past Tense Responses

Was it raining when you left the house this morning?

¿Estaba lloviendo cuando saliste de casa esta mañana?

Past Continuous

What were you doing when the power went out?

¿Qué estabas haciendo cuando se fue la luz?

Past Continuous

While we were walking in the park, we saw a rare bird.

Mientras caminábamos por el parque, vimos un pájaro raro.

Past Continuous

They were arguing about politics when I entered the room.

Estaban discutiendo sobre política cuando entré en la habitación.

Past Continuous

He was constantly interrupting me during the presentation.

Él me estaba interrumpiendo constantemente durante la presentación.

Past Continuous

I was studying all night while my friends were out partying.

Estuve estudiando toda la noche mientras mis amigos estaban de fiesta.

Past Continuous

Yes, I was studying when the fire alarm went off.

Sí, estaba estudiando cuando se activó la alarma de incendios.

Past Tense Responses

Had you ever seen such a beautiful sunset before that day?

¿Alguna vez habías visto un atardecer tan hermoso antes de ese día?

Past Perfect

I hadn’t realized how serious the situation was until I read the article.

No me había dado cuenta de lo grave que era la situación hasta que leí el artículo.

Past Perfect

No, I hadn’t seen him at the party.

No, no lo había visto en la fiesta.

Past Tense Responses

She had already finished the report before the meeting started.

Ella ya había terminado el informe antes de que comenzara la reunión.

Past Perfect

By the time we arrived, they had already left.

Para cuando llegamos, ellos ya se habían ido.

Past Perfect

He had studied French for five years before moving to Paris.

Él había estudiado francés durante cinco años antes de mudarse a París.

Past Perfect

We had never met her before the conference.

Nunca la habíamos conocido antes de la conferencia.

Past Perfect

The film had already started when we entered the cinema.

La película ya había comenzado cuando entramos al cine.

Past Perfect

I had lost my keys and didn’t know how to get back home.

Había perdido mis llaves y no sabía cómo volver a casa.

Past Perfect

Yes, I had heard about the incident before you mentioned it.

Sí, ya había oído sobre el incidente antes de que lo mencionaras.

Past Tense Responses

Yes, he did apologize after the misunderstanding.

Sí, él se disculpó después del malentendido.

Past Tense Responses

He won the award because he worked hard and stayed focused.

Él ganó el premio porque trabajó duro y se mantuvo enfocado.

Past Simple

They visited Rome and tried authentic Italian food.

Visitaron Roma y probaron comida italiana auténtica.

Past Simple

We watched the documentary and discussed it afterwards.

Vimos el documental y lo discutimos después.

Past Simple

I bought a new laptop because the old one broke down.

Compré un portátil nuevo porque el viejo se averió.

Past Simple

Reductor Paradigma 2 después de la lección POST Parte 3 - Historia Idioms, Slangs, Expressions and Vocabulary - Choco Inglés

Frase en inglés

Traducción al español

Tipo reducción

Tiempo

Verbo Clave

Is she killing it in her career?

¿Está ella haciendo un excelente trabajo en su carrera?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Be (is) + killing

Yes, she’s killing it.

Sí, lo está haciendo muy bien.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Be (is) + killing

Is her job to die for?

¿Su trabajo es muy envidiable?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Be

Yes, her job is to die for.

Sí, su trabajo es muy envidiable.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Be

Are they tearing their hair out?

¿Están muy frustrados?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente continuo

Be (are) + tearing

Yes, they are tearing their hair out.

Sí, están muy frustrados.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente continuo

Be (are) + tearing

Does she give a hoot?

¿Le importa?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Do (does) + give

No, she doesn’t give a hoot.

No, no le importa.

Afirmación Positiva

Presente

Do (does) + give

Is this café your jam?

¿Este café es tu lugar favorito?

Pregunta Positiva

Presente

Be

Yes, this café is my jam.
